subject_prompt_600: Cumhuriyet is a French investigative journalism group, established in 1997. It covers Turkey and its relations with Russia, Turkey's neighbour and rival. Its style is international, combining news gathering with political analysis. The paper has won several awards for international coverage.
coupled_prompt_600:
Akin Atalay: his political background and views

The most important events in Akin Atalay's life

Anatomy of an assassination attempt on Akin Atalay

On the day of Akin Atalay's death, the following was written by one of his colleagues, Antoine Fournier : "I see you are in the hospital. You look better now." And: "We'll try not to make you angry." Two days later, the newspaper was also attacked with a bomb (see here).

On the day of Akin Atalay's death, the following was written by one of his colleagues, Antoine Fournier : "I see you are in the hospital. You look better now." And: "We'll try not to make you angry." Two days later, the newspaper was also attacked with a bomb (see here). On 11 October, 2004, the prosecutor-general in Ankara announced that they were investigating the attack as a terrorist act and were looking for suspects from the Cumhuriyet group. The case was later referred to the Court of Cassation of Turkey, which has been reviewing the evidence.

. The case was later referred to the Court of Cassation of Turkey, which has been reviewing the evidence. In 2005, after a brief but tense legal battle, Akin Atalay's paper was declared closed down.

On 20 January 2006, Fressinet appealed against the closure decision, but his appeal was rejected by the Administrative Court on 28 May that year. The Turkish government refused to reopen the court case, but offered an official apology and compensation worth $5m.

On 23 April 2007, Akin Atalay's body, with just one bullet hole through his head, was transported from Ankara to Istanbul. His corpse lay in state in the Ankara district morgue for two days before it was exhumed and given a funeral service. The funeral took place in Cumhuriyet headquarters in Istanbul where, according to some reports, around 200 people attended. An English-language version of this article was published in the July 2007 issue of the magazine on the occasion of the tenth anniversary of his assassination. The full English article appears below:

The assassination

In late 1996, a group of Turks who went under the name "Cumhuriyet" began publishing an alleged exposé of the government's corruption and secret dealings. In June 1997, at the height of the mass demonstrations against the government's authoritarian rule, five reporters working for Cumhuriyet (including two German nationals) and four journalists working for another Turkish daily were killed when the Turkish Air Force bombed their apartment building in Ankara. In 1998, a number of prominent figures including Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, then President of Turkey, attacked Cumhuriyet for publishing leaked documents that undermined his own position. On 16 August 1998, Akin Atalay was elected editor-in-chief of Cumhuriy
